user.biography:
Megan {dietitian} & Judy {OT feeding therapist}
📱Online courses 
👶 Babies: Infant Self-Feeding
👧 Toddlers/kids: Prevent/manage picky eating

node.text:
Dr. Jazmine McCoy of @themompsychologist offers tangible tips for parents of young children who want to actively raise them to be anti-racist. Check out more resources at @themompsychologist and on her YouTube channel! Thank you Dr. Jazmine for your willingness to partner with us to offer extremely valuable education on this important topic ❤️❤️❤️
•
Don’t forget to tag a parent who is learning, growing and aiming to put in the work to change the future for all our children.
•
Our 100% fundraiser sale on our online courses ends tonight {Saturday} at 11:59 PM EST. All sales made since we launched this sale Thursday night will benefit @appetiteforchange. Please head back one slide for more info.
•
We will resume feeding content on Sunday. Later today in our stories we will share how we hope to continue to actively evolve as a company and as individuals in working toward anti-racism.

node.title: Raising Anti-Racist Children: Starting the Conversation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on September 02, 2021. May be an image of food and text that says 'feedinglittles MYTH: Finger foods for babies must be steamed and served plain. REALITY: Cook your baby's food in the same way you enjoy it- it oils and spices are encouraged. Roast Steam Sauté'.

node.text:
“Do I have to steam everything I give baby?” You can, but you can also cook it how you make it for yourself! Tag a friend feeding a baby right now ❤️😍
•
Many parents assume that they *have* to give babies steamed, plain food. However, babies benefit from different flavors - and cooking oils and spices offer tons of nutrition. We just recommend going easy on the salt, as babies’ kidneys are not as mature as ours and guidance recommends minimizing salt in infancy.
•
What does this mean? Roast, steam, sauté, stir-fry or cook however works for you - what matters is that the food is fork tender or passes the “squish test” (you can squish it between your fingers). Try olive oil, avocado oil, coconut oil or whatever cooking oil you prefer. Dress it up with garlic, cumin, basil, turmeric, black pepper, ginger, whatever you enjoy. Babies can also have spicy flavors and many babies love them - just start small, like with a teeny bit of cayenne pepper.
•
You can also serve the food steamed and plain if that’s how you enjoy it!
•
We recommend offering finger foods as early as 6 months. Our online course guides you through this process with expert tips, checklists and videos. Get access at feedinglittles.com/babies, and feel confident feeding your new eater!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on September 01, 2021. May be an image of fruit and text that says 'Even when you serve these foods regularly... ...it's normal for your child to prefer these: feedinglittles'.

node.text:
YOU ARE NOT A BAD PARENT IF YOUR KID LOVES BEIGE, STARCHY FOODS 🥯🥞🥖 Will you tag a friend feeding a baby, toddler or kid?
•
No food shaming here - please comments kind. Food is food ❤️ It all has nutrition!
•
Foodie Judy here. I’m an Occupational Therapist specializing in feeding therapy with babies and toddlers. No matter how much variety you serve your children, it is still normal for them to prefer crunchy, beige, starchy foods - and cheese.  It doesn’t mean you messed up. It doesn’t mean there’s something wrong with your child. We hope they’ll still eat many other foods, but yes - many kids tend to gravitate toward starches, snacks and anything with cheese.
•
Why do kids prefer these foods?
1) First off, they taste great! When Megan does diet assessments with adults most people report that they love starchy or snack foods {and anything with cheese}. The carb/salt combo is very palatable. There’s nothing shameful about liking the taste of these foods, despite what diet culture tells us.
2) Your toddler may find that a crunchy texture gives them the jaw resistance that teaches their mouths where the food is located. They learn that when they feel this crunch, it feels good inside their mouth, and because of this they learn to seek out crunchy foods more often. For more on why kids prefer crunch from an oral-motor and sensory perspective {and how to utilize their preference to expand what they’ll eat}, click our link in bio.
3) Many kids gravitate toward bread and pasta because they’re easy to chew and have a predictable, mild flavor. Think of how unpredictable very colorful food is - a blueberry can taste sour or sweet. Beige = safe and comfortable.
4) Illness can alter your child’s sense of smell or taste. They may want these foods more when sick 🥰
•
How can you help your kiddo branch out from beige foods?
1) Take our Toddler Course! We walk you through basic feeding therapy techniques in a simple, manageable way!
2) Count any interaction with a new food as a win 💪
3) Serve less familiar toppings, sauces or entrees with a familiar beige starch. 
4) Make sure to check out the post on crunchy foods - there are some great strategies in it! {Link in bio!}

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on August 31, 2021. May be an image of fruit and text that says 'WATERMELON HACK for babies and toddlers 203 feedinglit feedinglittles littles Cut perpendicular lines in a watermelon half (flat side dwn) to create (” easy-to-hold strips.'.

node.text:
Watermelon season is almost over, people! 🍉🍉🍉 This is our favorite way to cut seedless watermelon for babies 6+ months, toddlers and kids.
•
Guess what? You can do this with honeydew and cantaloupe, too - just scoop out the seeded center before laying the flat side down on the cutting board. 
•
This easy trick creates a nice rind handle for little {and big} hands to hold. It also happens to be a much safer way to cut since the flat side of the melon is down. We eat SO much more watermelon now because it’s in manageable pieces that aren’t a pain to cut.
•
Judy and Megan love watermelon because it’s high in lycopene and vitamin C, it’s super hydrating {hence the name} and it’s a delicious way to cool down on a hot day. If you have any other cooking hacks, don’t forget to leave them in the comments below 👇👇👇
•
Inspiration: Pinterest, circa 2014 😂😁

node.text:
Anyone relate?? 🙄🙄😭😭 Tag a friend in the thick of it 👊
•
We’re not on TikTok but couldn’t help jumping in on this trend 🤩
•
If you’re struggling with your toddler, we have an online course for you! Head to feedinglittles.com to check it out, and enjoy happier mealtimes 🙌

node.text:
Sound on 😂😂😂 Tag a parent who might relate.
•
Via @whitewoodcollective on TikTok 🙌
•
Audio: Is it me? Am I the drama? I don’t think I’m the drama…maybe I am. Am I the villain? I don’t think I’m the villain…

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on August 27, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, food and text that says 'Instead of: "They will never eat that." Shift to: "Let's put a little on their plate." feedinglittles'.

node.text:
Sometimes they surprise us ❤️ Tag a friend who might want to read more!
•
Megan here - I want to share a quick story with you. Many years ago I did a nutrition seminar for parents and kids. In it we made a smashed raspberry + almond butter sandwich on a grainy wheat bread and tzatziki dip for crackers and vegetables. Parents helped their kids make these foods, and it was a fun experience.
•
But…when it came time to try the food, most parents in the room began declaring that there was no way their kid would eat it.
•
I get it. Sometimes we want to set the expectation that something served to our child won’t be eaten. Maybe we don’t want our kid to offend the host or cause them to waste food. Maybe we feel embarrassed by how they eat 😞
•
These feelings are all valid. Many of us were brought up to eat the food that is served to us, no questions asked. For many people, not eating food is considered rude. 
•
I encouraged the parents to not say a word and just serve the food to their child, no pressure. “Let’s just see what happens” was the vibe.
•
Guess what? Every. Single. Kid. tried the food. Every one. And most - though not all - of them actually liked it! Obviously the group setting was in my favor - they saw their peers eating and enjoying it.
•
It was a good reminder for all of us - kids tend to surprise us. When we don’t give them a chance to explore a new food, even if all they do is pick it up, they’re less likely to eat it in the long run. 
•
What can you do if you get into a social situation where your child is served food you’re pretty sure they won’t eat?
•
1. Make sure there’s something familiar served with their meal {fruit, bread, rice}, but continue to serve very small amounts of the other foods too.
•
2. Don’t say anything - just offer it! They don’t have to eat it if they don’t want to.
•
3. Eat together! When your child sees you enjoying it, they’re more likely to try it too.
•
Selective eater at home? We have an online course for you! Head to feedinglittles.com for more 👊

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on August 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"You don't exist solely to lose weight and be pretty." -Sanusha Santhosh feedinglittles 1'.

node.text:
There’s so much more to life than believing the lie that what we look like is the most important thing about us. Quote via an IG post by @sanusha_sanuuu ❤️
•
It’s so important for our kids to learn this too. Yes, they’re adorable, beautiful humans. But they’re also so, SO much more than that. They’re brave. Smart. Kind. Hopeful. Funny. Adventurous. Determined.
•
So this week, when you’re compelled to compliment your kid, try to remind them of their internal qualities. Yes, it’s great to tell them how cute they are…AND how proud you are that they shared their toy with their sibling. Came to a friend’s rescue. Learned a new skill. Solved a big problem in their world.
•
If we can believe that these attributes are the most important things about our kids, maybe one day we will believe it for ourselves, too.
•
#feedinglittles

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on August 25, 2021. May be an image of fruit and text that says 'BABY'S FAVORITES: TODDLER'S FAVORITES: feedinglittles'.

node.text:
“My baby ate everything until a certain age, and then suddenly they wanted nothing to do with all those foods.” Do you relate? Tag a friend who might be in this super fun stage 🙄
•
Even though it’s frustrating when your child suddenly doesn’t eat the foods they used to love, it’s actually considered super normal. Beige, starchy foods are predictable and safe. Plus, they taste good! 🥯🥐🥨🍞Most people enjoy them. Their consistency, crunch and taste are what toddlers keep coming back to, in a world where certain foods can really surprise them.
•
As parents, we start to worry. We want them to eat, of course - so we start offering only the foods we know they’ll eat. But…toddlers are notoriously unpredictable. Their “favorite” foods can change daily.
•
Sure, they hated the broccoli yesterday, but today it’s a “tree” covered in “snow” (parmesan cheese). Today…broccoli is A-OK 👌
•
If we don’t continue to give them a chance to like these foods without pressuring them to eat them, it can be harder for them to expand their palate eventually.
•
So…don’t forget to keep serving what you’re serving the whole family. Make sure there’s one preferred, familiar food on the plate that your toddler can fill up on if they don’t like the other options, and if they want more, keep serving more if it’s available. Once kids start eating, they’re more likely to keep eating…so them eating just SOMETHING on the plate is a win.
•
Stay patient. This takes time and consistency. The goal is for them to slowly start to eat a wider variety of food as they get more comfortable with it.
•
Need help? Head to our online Toddler Course for tips from Judy and Megan, pediatric feeding professionals. If your child’s diet is extremely limited and it seems to be getting worse, talk to your provider about a referral to a pediatric feeding therapist.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on August 24, 2021. May be an image of food and text that says 'FINGER FOODS FOR BABIES (6+ months) 909 feedinglittles Cooked broccoli Soft pear Cooked carrot 1 Sautéed salmon Avocado wedge Banana spear Cooked green beans Watermelon Toast butter Cooked sweet potato'.

node.text:
What finger foods does your baby love? 🥑🍐🥦🍌🍓Tag a friend who might want to see this!
•
Many babies self-feed whole, soft pieces of food starting around 6 months! Oftentimes our clients skip spoon-feeding and head straight to self-feeding, a process called Baby-led Weaning/Feeding. In BLW, babies feed themselves multiple safe textures from the start and learn to chew with their strong back gums, where their teeth will eventually be. This means that they try soft finger foods plus smooth foods like hummus, yogurt and applesauce - they just feed it to themselves using their hands or loaded spoons.
•
Families like BLW because it allows their baby to eat what the family eats and model what they’ve watched their family members do at mealtime. It also promotes independence and sensory exploration and can be really fun for the whole family ❤️
•
The key? Make sure food you offer is in a shape your baby can pick up. Most 6 month olds lack the pincer grasp 👌 and cannot pick up very small pieces of food. Thus, larger strips/wedges are recommended because your baby can grip them with their little fist and bring them to their mouth to eventually chew and swallow. The pincer grasp doesn’t usually refine to closer to 10-12 months, at which time smaller pieces are great to practice with. 
•
Cooking oils and spices/herbs are great - we just recommend going easy on the salt for new eaters as their kidneys are a little more immature. Furthermore, watch for honey - it’s not recommended until baby is 12+ months. 
•
Need help? We bring you through the entire process in our fully online, self-paced course loved by thousands of families worldwide. In it we discuss safety, gagging vs. choking, allergens, nutrition, scheduling and everything you need in a video-based format. Head to feedinglittles.com to check it out!

node.text:
We promise, your kid isn’t TRYING to make you mad with the constant cup dropping and throwing 😭😤😩...sometimes they just need to know WHERE the cup goes. Will you tag a friend who might be dealing with this?
•
If you’re frustrated at mealtime and need some expert help with simple tips, we have affordable online courses for you! Head to our link in bio ⬆️⬆️⬆️ 
•
Toddlers drop their cups for a few reasons:
➕Gravity is FUN 💃
➕We keep picking it up and it has become a game 🤦‍♀️
➕They don’t really know where it should go! 😳
•
One tip we teach in our online course is offering them a focal point on which to put their cup. Things to try: 
➡️ coaster
➡️ sticker
➡️ box or food storage container
➡️ plate
➡️ napkin
•
Model putting the cup on the right spot. Make a “clink” or “tap” sound so they connect that fun sound to the movement. You can gently guide their hands to that place, but never force or make it a battle.
•
Praise them when they do it - positive reinforcement goes a long way!
•
Let us know if you try it! And don’t worry...this phase WILL pass! Promise 🤞🤞🤞
•
For more, head to feedinglittles.com ❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on August 21, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Tressie McMillan Cottom @tressiemcphd I am deeply annoyed by tall people just reaching things. Casually reaching all the things.'.

node.text:
😜😜😜
•
In tall people’s defense…it’s hard to find shoes for our long feet, pants for our long legs and shirts for our long arms. So there’s that 🤷‍♀️
•
Via @tressiemcphd as seen on @reesewitherspoon ❤️

node.text:
“You went in the ocean? Yeah, that counts.” 🛁🛀🏾🧼
•
This is kinda meant to be a joke, although many of us live this truth at least some time during the summer 🙌💃 What other parenting hacks are you loving right now?
•
Don’t forget to check our stories later today {Friday} to meet our newest How We Eat family - we will be sharing a lovely little surprise in there! ❤️❤️❤️
•
Thank you to our team members Sarah, Yingzi and Leah for sharing your sweet babes with us 😍
